abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Energy Project of Vietnam had
            the following ratings: outcomes were satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was low or negligible, Bank performance
            was satisfactory, and borrower performance was satisfactory.
            The lessons learned included: 1) A clear roadmap to achieve
            the final objective of the Borrower and of the Bank support
            should be developed and be the basis to design the specific
            interventions and facilitate their development; 2) The
            decision to decentralize Rural Electrification to the final
            implementing agencies proved to be efficient and effective
            to successfully implement the project and exceed the number
            of communes and households electrified; 3) Rural
            electrification projects have a low financial rate of return
            and should be designed to give the room and stimulate the
            mobilization of funding from other sources; 4) Consultation
            and obtaining strong local commitments are essential in
            projects involving a large numbers of parties; 5) The
            project had a large numbers of sub-components, to be
            implemented in difficult areas during a long period of time.
            Flexibility is essential, both in term of physical scope and
            approval, to allow for fast adjustment to unexpected
            conditions (and in this case cost savings) that may arise in
            implementation and increase the benefit of the project; and
            6) Projects with local implementing agencies and/or covering
            several local areas need a TTL and team based in the field
            to actively and effectively coordinate and inter-act with
            the client and implementing agencies, and to closely monitor
            progress addressing fast problems and delays.

repnme.cdata!:
Viet Nam - Rural Energy Project :
            resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This resettlement action plan aims to
            compensate all project affected households and organizations
            (PAPs) and aid them in maintaining their standard of living
            or bettering it. Compensation will be at substitution rates
            or market prices. Compensation for houses, buildings, and
            trees must be at replacement cost regardless of
            depreciation. All PAPs are entitled to compensation and
            rehabilitation whether or not they hold legal entitlements
            to the land. No households will have to resettle because
            removed houses will be reconstructed on land near the
            original site. Households with houses demolished in part
            will be compensated in cash at the substitution rate. The
            total amount of compensation issued to the household has to
            equal the cost of materials and labor needed to reconstruct
            the demolished section of the house. If demolition of the
            damaged section damages the remaining sections of the house,
            compensation will be added to pay the cost of repairs. PAPs
            losing agricultural lands will be compensated in cash or opt
            for land for land compensation. Compensation for crops will
            be given in cash at current market rates calculated on the
            productive average of the last three years. Compensation for
            trees will be provided in cash at substitution rates. In
            addition to direct compensation for losses, PAPs will
            receive other subsidies.

repnme.cdata!:
Vietnam - Rural Energy Project : ethnic
            minority development plan

abstracts.cdata!:
Within the framework of the Rural Energy
            Project, the subproject in the newly established Dak Nong
            Province, will reduce electricity losses, and increase
            availability of electricity. However, it is foreseen land
            acquisition will occur, and some ethnic minorities will be
            negatively affected within the project area, thus, this
            Ethnic Minority Development Plan seeks to ensure within the
            development process, the full respect for minorities'
            dignity, human rights, and cultural uniqueness, aiming at
            minimizing adverse effects, and ensuring they receive
            culturally compatible socioeconomic benefits. It is
            recommended that power lines be located in accordance to the
            needs and priorities of ethnic minorities, following public
            consultations. Construction has been scheduled in order to
            avoid crop harvesting; notably, with the 12 month
            construction period, to work shifts have been allowed, so
            that construction would start right after harvesting, and
            complete before the following crop. In addition, impacts on
            temporary crops should be compensated at market prices. The
            project design, and construction works take into
            consideration ecological, spiritual, and cultural issues,
            including avoiding construction around sensitive areas,
            which are nonetheless, usually at some distance from the
            right of way (ROW). A program of information and education
            on electricity safety, health and social issues will be
            developed to inform ethnic minorities in the project area.
            Land losses will be compensated, in a suitable, culturally
            acceptable manner, in accordance with resettlement
            safeguards. Training assistance will be provided,
            particularly gender assistance, through special
            consultations with, and training for women, paying careful
            attention to women heads of households, in areas such as
            credit, agricultural extension, use of fertilizers, among others.

repnme.cdata!:
Viet Nam - Rural Energy Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The report is an environmental
            assessment of the Rural Energy Project in Vietnam. Following
            a review of the legal, and administrative arrangements, it
            assesses the analysis of alternatives for the installation
            of transmission lines (TL), and for substations location, to
            minimize environmental, and resettlement impacts. Taking
            into account the Environmental Law, the project design
            avoids dense forest areas, and preferably selects forest
            areas of low economic, and ecological value, for both
            temporary access roads, and installation of TLs. Surveys
            revealed there are no cultural, or archaeological sites
            along the project area; however, if local sites are
            discovered, authorities from the Electricity of Vietnam
            (EVN) shall notify local authorities. Nonetheless, during
            construction, environmental concerns feature vegetation
            clearance, soil erosion due to excavations for temporary
            access road construction, and due to equipment/material
            transportation. Measures to mitigate adverse impacts include
            the installation of retaining fences to prevent slope
            erosion, followed by vegetation, and tree planting to avoid
            soil erosion. In such cases where slopes, or swamps cannot
            be avoided for the installation of poles, pole-footings will
            be redesigned to suit ground conditions. Hunting, and lumber
            activities will be strictly forbidden, in compliance with
            the Forestry Control Branch regulations. Local health
            facilities will be available at construction camps to ensure
            medical, and hygienic measures, particularly in the
            prevention of endemic, and waterborne diseases.
            Electromagnetic fields at the edge of the right of way, will
            be kept below 5 KV/m, in accordance with international standards.
